articles.title: Old Bones Tell Stories of Ancient Animals
articles.summary: Scientists have found tiny chemicals inside old bones from animals that lived millions of years ago. These chemicals, called metabolites, help us learn about the animals' health, what they ate, and the world they lived in. The bones came from places in Africa like Tanzania and South Africa. By studying these metabolites, researchers discovered that the ancient climate was warmer and wetter than today. They used a tool called mass spectrometry to see the chemicals. This new method lets us understand daily life in the past, not just family trees from DNA. It's like reading a diary written in bone!

articles.title: Scientists Test Eating Times Without Eating Less
articles.summary: Scientists did a study to see if eating only during certain hours helps people's health without eating less food. They tested 31 women who ate the same amount of food but at different times: early from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. or late from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. After two weeks, they found no big changes in health things like how the body uses sugar or fat. But they did see that eating times can change the body's internal clock, which is like a timer inside us that tells us when to sleep or be active. This means that just changing when you eat, without eating less, might not make you healthier. The study was done by scientists in Germany and published in a science journal.

articles.title: Nerves Can Heal at Any Age After a Back Injury
articles.summary: Scientists studied how people recover after a spinal cord injury, which happens when the nerves in the back are damaged. They found that age does not stop nerves from healing. Older people and younger people both regained strength and feeling in their arms and legs similarly. However, older adults had more trouble with daily activities like walking, bathing, and eating on their own. The study followed over 2,000 patients for one year in Europe. This research helps doctors understand that age is not a barrier to nerve recovery, but older people might need extra help with everyday tasks. It could lead to better treatments for everyone with spinal cord injuries.

articles.title: Brain Clues That Warn About Alzheimer's Early
articles.summary: Scientists in Singapore found that the brain's cleaning system can get blocked in people who might get Alzheimer's disease. These blockages are called enlarged perivascular spaces and can be seen on MRI scans, which are pictures of the brain. The study looked at nearly 1,000 people in Singapore, including those with normal thinking and those with early memory problems. This research is important because it focuses on Asian people, who are often not studied enough in Alzheimer's research. Finding these blockages early could help doctors detect Alzheimer's sooner, giving more time to help slow down symptoms like memory loss. The brain uses these spaces to remove harmful waste, and when they get clogged, it might be a warning sign for the disease.

articles.title: Wales' New Green Farming Plan After Brexit
articles.summary: Wales has started a new plan to help farmers after leaving the EU. This plan gives money to farms that do things to help the environment, like taking care of land and using fewer chemicals. Farmers must manage at least 10% of their land as a habitat to join. Some farmers are happy, but others, like dairy farmers, find it hard because their land might not qualify. There were protests before because people thought the plan was not good, but after talks, it is now better. The government says this is a big moment for Wales. Farms used to get money from the EU based on how much land they had, but now they get paid for being green. The plan has rules like keeping hedges healthy and learning about sustainable farming online. More money is available for farms that do extra environmental work. People hope many farmers will join to make the countryside better.

articles.title: Mystery of Women in a Medieval Cemetery
articles.summary: Archaeologists in Wales are trying to solve a mystery about women buried in a medieval cemetery. They found 58 skeletons from the 6th or 7th century, and almost all are women. The team discovered a small building outline, beads, and other items that show the women might have been part of a religious community. The graves are shallow and cut into rock, and people wanted to be buried near the building, sometimes sharing graves. This helps us learn about life long ago and who these women were.
